items.title: Ancient interstellar comet sweeps past Earth with unexplained nickel emissions

featured_image.name: You can still see comet 3I/ATLAS in the night sky. Here’s how.

items.description: An ancient visitor from beyond our solar system swept past Earth early Friday morning, offering scientists an unprecedented opportunity to study material forged around a distant star billions of years ago. Comet 3I/ATLAS, the third confirmed interstellar object ever detected, came within 168 million miles of our planet at approximately 1 a.m. EST, according to NASA[1][2][3]. While posing no danger to Earth, the comet's unusual metal emissions have left astronomers scrambling to explain its peculiar chemistry.

items.title: Trump envoys host Miami talks on Ukraine, Gaza ceasefires

featured_image.name: Trump officials' meeting with Russian in Miami spurs questions about Ukraine proposal

items.description:
President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff is convening a series of high-stakes diplomatic meetings in Miami this weekend aimed at advancing peace efforts in both Ukraine and Gaza, as the administration pursues simultaneous breakthroughs on two of the world's most intractable conflicts.

On Friday, Witkoff is meeting separately with two distinct groups. He is hosting senior officials from Qatar, Egypt, and Turkey to discuss advancing the stalled second phase of the Gaza ceasefire[1][2][3]. The White House envoy is also meeting with national security advisers from Ukraine, Germany, France, and the United Kingdom to discuss the U.S.-backed peace plan for Ukraine[4][5][6].

On Saturday, Witkoff and Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and adviser, are scheduled to meet with Kirill Dmitriev, who heads Russia's sovereign wealth fund and serves as a Kremlin envoy, to present the latest developments from talks with Ukrainian and European officials[1][7][8]. A separate meeting with Ukrainian national security adviser Rustem Umerov is also expected this weekend[9][10].

items.title: Brazil court rejects Bolsonaro's coup appeal

featured_image.name: BRAZIL-POLITICS-JUSTICE-TRIAL

items.description: A Brazilian Supreme Court judge on Friday rejected former President Jair Bolsonaro's latest appeal against his 27-year coup conviction, ruling it inadmissible because only one of five judges voted against his conviction—short of the two required for the appeal to proceed[1][2][3][4]. Justice Alexandre de Moraes, who presided over Bolsonaro's trial, said he did not recognize the fresh appeal, which Bolsonaro's lawyers filed three days after the 70-year-old began serving his sentence in November[1][3]. Separately, Federal Police confirmed Friday that an official medical exam found Bolsonaro has a hernia requiring surgery and that a nerve-blocking procedure for violent hiccups is "technically appropriate," with doctors recommending the procedures take place "as soon as possible"[1][2].

items.title: Romney calls for higher taxes on wealthy to save Social Security

featured_image.name: Mitt Romney calls for higher taxes on wealthy in op-ed

items.description:
Former Senator Mitt Romney reversed his long-held position on taxing the rich, publishing an op-ed in The New York Times on Friday urging Congress to raise taxes on wealthy Americans to prevent Social Security's collapse[1][2][3].

"On the tax front, it's time for rich people like me to pay more," Romney wrote, warning that the Social Security Trust Fund faces depletion by 2034, which would trigger benefit cuts of approximately 23 percent for tens of millions of retirees[1][4][5]. The Utah Republican, who left the Senate in January after declining to seek reelection in 2024, estimated his own net worth at $253 million, accumulated largely during his tenure at private equity firm Bain Capital[6][7][8].

items.title: China tests drone refueling tech that could extend strike range

featured_image.name: China’s drone carrier Jiu Tian takes flight to signal PLA swarm capacity boost

items.description:
China has successfully tested autonomous aerial refueling technology for military drones, a breakthrough that could double the operational range of its newly unveiled Jiu Tian drone carrier and bring major U.S. cities within reach, according to a report published Thursday.

Northwestern Polytechnical University conducted what appears to be China's first openly reported autonomous aerial refueling flight test, using two unidentified unmanned aerial vehicles, the South China Morning Post reported[1][2][1]. The receiving drone autonomously located, tracked and docked with a tanker aircraft during high-speed formation flights using a vision-based navigation system that achieved a 99% detection success rate with centimeter-level positioning accuracy[2][2].

The development gains significance from Northwestern Polytechnical University's direct involvement with China's Jiu Tian drone program[1][2][1]. The heavy-duty unmanned platform, which completed its maiden flight on December 11 in Shaanxi Province[3][4][5], can carry more than 200 loitering munitions and has an official range of 7,000 kilometers[1][1]. Combined with in-flight refueling capabilities, its effective strike radius could double to approximately 14,000 kilometers, placing Washington, New York and Miami within plausible reach[1][1][2].

items.title: US strikes ISIS sites across Syria after Iowa Guardsmen killed

featured_image.name: U.S. Strikes Islamic State Targets in Syria

items.description:
The United States unleashed a sweeping military operation against Islamic State targets across Syria on Friday, deploying fighter jets, attack helicopters, and artillery in retaliation for an ambush that killed two Iowa National Guard soldiers and a civilian interpreter six days earlier[1][2].

The airstrikes, dubbed "Operation Hawkeye Strike" in honor of the fallen Iowans' home state, targeted numerous suspected ISIS locations throughout central Syria, focusing on weapon storage facilities and other structures supporting terrorist operations[1][3]. A U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, characterized the bombardments as "a massive attack" that continued for several hours into early Saturday morning Syrian time[1]. Social media reports from Syria indicated widespread explosions across extensive areas of the country[1].

The operation came after Sgt. William Nathaniel Howard, 29, of Marshalltown, and Sgt. Edgar Brian Torres-Tovar, 25, of Des Moines, were killed alongside civilian interpreter Ayad Mansoor Sakat, 54, during a December 13 attack in Palmyra[3][4][5]. The soldiers were conducting a key leader engagement with local Syrian partners when a lone gunman—identified as a Syrian security forces member with suspected ISIS sympathies—opened fire before being killed[1][5][6].

items.title: Blue Origin to launch first wheelchair user to space Saturday

featured_image.name: For the 1st time ever, a person who uses a wheelchair will fly to space

items.description:
Blue Origin postponed a landmark spaceflight Thursday that would send the first wheelchair user to space, but the company now aims to launch Saturday morning from West Texas.

The NS-37 mission, initially scheduled for December 18, was scrubbed due to technical issues during preflight checks. Blue Origin announced the launch window will now open at 9 a.m. EST on December 20, with a live webcast beginning 20 minutes before liftoff[1][2].

Michaela "Michi" Benthaus, an aerospace engineer at the European Space Agency, is poised to make history as the first wheelchair user to cross the Kármán line—the internationally recognized boundary of space at 62 miles above Earth. Benthaus, who uses a wheelchair following a 2018 mountain biking accident that caused a spinal cord injury, has continued her career in space research, completing zero-gravity research flights in 2022[3][4][5].

items.title: Leicester engineers design magnetic cloaking for any shape

featured_image.name: New 'cloaking device' concept shields electronics from ...

items.description:
Engineers at the University of Leicester have unveiled a design framework for magnetic cloaking devices that can shield electronics from disruptive magnetic fields, marking the first practical approach for objects of any shape. The research, published December 18 in Science Advances, offers potential applications from medical imaging to fusion energy[1][2][3].

Led by Dr. Harold Ruiz from Leicester's School of Engineering, the team developed a physics-informed optimization framework that solves Maxwell's equations to design magnetic cloaks for arbitrarily shaped structures[1][2]. Previous magnetic cloaking demonstrations were restricted to simple cylinders or spheres, limiting real-world applicability[1][2][3].

The devices work by manipulating magnetic field lines to flow around objects as if they weren't there, making the cloaked object magnetically invisible while leaving surrounding fields undisturbed[2][3]. The design combines two materials with opposing magnetic properties: an inner superconducting layer that repels magnetic fields and an outer soft ferromagnetic layer that attracts them, creating a balanced effect that eliminates field distortion[1][2][3].

items.title: AI stocks surge as Micron earnings fuel sector rally

featured_image.name: Micron stock soars on earnings beat amid 'unprecedented' AI-fueled demand for memory chips

items.description:
Artificial intelligence stocks surged Friday, driving major indexes higher and signaling renewed investor confidence in a sector that has weathered concerns over valuations and returns in recent weeks.

The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite climbed approximately 1.2%, extending Thursday's 1.4% gain[1][2][3], while the S&P 500 rose 0.8%[3][4]. Semiconductor stocks led the advance, with the PHLX Semiconductor Sector Index jumping nearly 3%[5].

Micron Technology continued its rally, gaining more than 6% Friday after soaring 10% Thursday on earnings that crushed Wall Street expectations[1][2][6]. The memory chip maker reported adjusted earnings of $4.78 per share on revenue of $13.64 billion, well above estimates, and provided guidance of approximately $18.70 billion for the current quarter versus the $14.20 billion analysts expected[6][7]. "We are more than sold out," the company stated during its earnings call[7].

Oracle jumped about 8% after announcing it would join an investor group acquiring a 15% stake in TikTok's U.S. operations through a deal valued at approaching $10 billion[1][8]. The agreement allows the social media platform to continue operating in the United States while addressing national security concerns[8][9].

Nvidia gained approximately 3.6%, while Advanced Micro Devices climbed nearly 6%[1][10]. Other AI-related stocks including Super Micro Computer, Palantir Technologies, and Arista Networks also posted gains[5].

items.title: Oracle and Nvidia fuel tech rally on TikTok deal, China chip review

featured_image.name: Nvidia considers increasing H200 chip output due to robust China demand, Reuters sources say

items.description:
US stock markets rose Friday, with technology shares leading a rebound as Oracle and Nvidia surged on deal-making news and renewed artificial intelligence optimism, capping a volatile week on Wall Street.

The S&P 500 gained 0.89% to close at 6,835.14, while the Nasdaq Composite jumped 1.17% to 23,274.60[1][2][3]. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.57%[2][3].

Oracle's stock soared more than 7% after TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew revealed the company signed agreements to create a US joint venture for the social media platform's American operations[4][5]. Under the deal, Oracle will hold a 15% stake alongside private equity firm Silver Lake and Abu Dhabi-based MGX, with the trio collectively owning 45% of the new entity set to take effect January 22, 2026[4][6]. Oracle will serve as the "trusted security partner" responsible for auditing compliance with national security terms[4].

Nvidia shares climbed 3.7% as the Trump administration initiated a review that could enable the chipmaker to sell its H200 AI processors to China[1][7]. The potential approval, which would come with a 25% government fee, reignited investor confidence in the AI sector after recent volatility over elevated valuations[8][9].

items.title: Trump blames federal job cuts for rising unemployment

featured_image.name: < Federal agencies are rehiring workers and spending more after DOGE's push to cut

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Friday defended the rising unemployment rate, attributing the increase entirely to his administration's sweeping reductions in the federal workforce as he criticized media outlets for failing to provide what he called proper context[1][2].

In a Truth Social post, Trump said unemployment rose to 4.5% "only because we are reducing the Government Workforce by numbers that have never been seen before," adding that "100% OF OUR NEW JOBS ARE IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR"[3][4]. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the unemployment rate actually reached 4.6% in November, the highest level since September 2021[5][6][7].

items.title: China weaponizes AI in cyberattacks on Western targets

featured_image.name: Anthropic warns of AI-driven hacking campaign linked to China

items.description:
Chinese state-sponsored hackers have weaponized artificial intelligence to conduct sophisticated cyberattacks against Western governments and corporations, marking a new phase in the escalating technological competition between Beijing and Washington.

On Thursday, nine U.S. lawmakers urged the Pentagon to add Chinese AI firm DeepSeek and other tech companies to a list of entities allegedly supporting China's military, intensifying scrutiny of Beijing's technology sector[1][2]. The move comes as tensions mount over China's use of advanced AI capabilities for both military and intelligence purposes.

items.title: Arizona scientists study microbes colonizing Icelandic lava

featured_image.name: Life on lava: How microbes colonize new habitats

items.description:
Scientists from the University of Arizona have documented how resilient microorganisms colonize fresh volcanic lava within hours, offering insights that could guide the search for ancient life on Mars.

The research team studied microbial communities on recently solidified lava flows from Iceland's Fagradalsfjall volcano, which erupted three times between 2021 and 2023. Their findings, published in Nature Communications Biology, reveal a predictable two-stage process of microbial succession on Earth's harshest new environments[1][2][3][4].

items.title: New York and Ontario partner on nuclear energy

featured_image.name: New York and Ontario sign agreement to bolster nuclear energy efforts

items.description:
New York Governor Kathy Hochul and Ontario Premier Doug Ford signed a landmark agreement Friday to jointly develop advanced nuclear energy technologies, marking a new era of cross-border energy cooperation amid rising demand for clean electricity and heightened trade tensions with the Trump administration[1][2][3][4].

The Memorandum of Understanding between the New York Power Authority and Ontario Power Generation establishes a framework for collaboration on both large-scale nuclear facilities and small modular reactors, which Ontario is currently building at the Darlington Nuclear Generating Station outside Toronto[1][3][5][4]. The deal aims to strengthen energy reliability, reduce costs, and accelerate decarbonization efforts in both regions[3][4].

items.title: 2025 space discoveries pave way for 2026 Moon missions

featured_image.name: 15 More of the Most Recent Space Discoveries from 2025

items.description:
As a rare interstellar comet makes its closest approach to Earth today, 2025 is culminating as one of the most productive years for space science, while 2026 promises historic aerospace achievements including the first crewed lunar mission in over half a century.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, detected by NASA's ATLAS telescope in Chile in July, passed within 168 million miles of Earth on December 19[1][2], marking only the third interstellar object ever discovered within our solar system. Multiple NASA missions, including Europa Clipper and Psyche, coordinated observations of this visitor traveling at 221,000 kilometers per hour[1][3].

items.title: Trump to announce drug price deals with pharma giants

featured_image.name: Trump unveils deal for AstraZeneca to cut Medicaid drug prices and join "TrumpRx" site

items.description:
President Donald Trump is set to announce deals with at least seven major pharmaceutical companies to lower prescription drug prices Friday afternoon at the White House, marking the latest expansion of his administration's "Most Favored Nation" pricing campaign.

GlaxoSmithKline, Merck, Sanofi, AbbVie, Bristol Myers Squibb, Gilead Sciences, Novartis, and Roche are among the companies expected to participate in the 1 p.m. briefing in the White House's Roosevelt Room, according to multiple sources[1][2][3]. The announcement comes after months of pressure from Trump, who in July sent letters to 17 pharmaceutical CEOs demanding they slash U.S. drug prices to match those overseas or face tariffs and other penalties[4][5].

items.title: Trump plan to dismantle Colorado climate center stalls funding

featured_image.name: Trump administration moves to dismantle prominent US weather ...abcnews.go.com › Politics › story

items.description:
President Donald Trump's plan to break up the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder has stalled a major government funding package, as Colorado's senators demanded protections for the climate research hub they say is under retaliatory attack.

Democratic Senators Michael Bennet and John Hickenlooper placed a hold on a five-bill Senate appropriations package late Thursday, blocking progress on spending legislation just days before Congress began its year-end recess[1][2]. The move came three days after White House budget director Russell Vought announced the administration would dismantle NCAR, calling it "one of the largest sources of climate alarmism in the country"[3][4].

"President Trump is attacking Colorado because we refuse to bend to his corrupt administration," the senators said in a joint statement[1]. "We are holding the Senate's appropriations package to demand full funding for NCAR."

The standoff left lawmakers scrambling as they face a January 30 funding deadline[2]. Senate Appropriations Chair Susan Collins told reporters Thursday evening that only one hold remained on the package after weeks of negotiations with fiscal conservatives, identifying the Colorado senators as the final obstacle[2][5].

items.title: Morgan Stanley leads race to underwrite SpaceX IPO

featured_image.name: SpaceX’s Next Big Launch Could Be an I.P.O.

items.description:
Morgan Stanley is emerging as the front-runner to secure a key underwriting role in SpaceX's highly anticipated initial public offering, positioning itself ahead of rivals Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan in what could become one of the largest public listings in history, according to sources familiar with the matter[1][2][3].

The bank's long-standing relationship with SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, dating back at least 15 years, gives it a significant edge in the competitive selection process known as a "bake-off," three sources told Reuters[1][2]. However, no banks have been finalized, and it remains uncertain whether Morgan Stanley will secure the coveted "lead left" underwriting position[1][2].

items.title: Lockheed, L3Harris win billions in satellite defense deals

featured_image.name: Lockheed Secures $2.3B NASA Contract to Develop NOAA GeoXO ...

items.description:
The Space Development Agency announced that Lockheed Martin and L3Harris Technologies secured major contracts to build missile tracking satellites as part of a broader $3.5 billion effort to counter advanced weapons threats[1][2].

Lockheed Martin received a contract worth more than $1 billion to build 18 space vehicles for the Tranche 3 Tracking Layer, while L3Harris won an $843 million award for an identical number of satellites[3][4][1]. The awards mark the latest expansion of the Pentagon's Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, a layered network of defense satellites in low Earth orbit designed to detect and track conventional and hypersonic missile threats[5][1].

items.title: Global markets crush U.S. stocks by widest margin since 2009

featured_image.name: Emerging markets set to outperform US stocks as dollar weakness continues, Cambridge says

items.description:
Artificial intelligence companies captured Wall Street's attention in 2025, but investors who diversified abroad reaped even bigger gains, as international markets delivered their strongest performance against U.S. stocks in more than three decades.

Nvidia, Tesla, and Palantir Technologies emerged as the most-viewed ticker pages on Yahoo Finance this year, with Nvidia alone attracting a quarter billion page views[1]. The AI chipmaker gained 30% in 2025, while Palantir soared 140%[1]. Despite the intense interest in U.S. tech stocks, the S&P 500 rose just 15% through December 18[2], trailing far behind international benchmarks.
